review.title: Random Forest for Malware Classification
review.abstract: The challenge in engaging malware activities involves the correct identification and classification of different malware variants. Various malwares incorporate code obfuscation methods that alters their code signatures effectively countering antimalware detection techniques utilizing static methods and signature database. In this study, we utilized an approach of converting a malware binary into an image and use Random Forest to classify various malware families. The resulting accuracy of 0.9562 exhibits the effectivess of the method in detecting malware

sections.heading: A. Data Preparation
sections.text: The resulting 8-bit vectors are then displayed as a grayscale image, as in Fig. 1. The conversion result of the malware binary files consists of images with different sizes and patterns as in Fig. 2. It is also worth noting that several malware creators add additional binary code patterns to their malware as a personal signature, such as the lower part of the image shown in Fig. 2. The malware images are resized in a two-dimensional matrix to have a uniform dataset. The resized images are rendered to n x n array with n = 32. Each resulting array of 1024 length is labeled with the corresponding malware family.The labeled arrays are merged into a csv file that would include the training set for the machine learning algorithm.

sections.heading: B. Classification
sections.text: Various research on malware and detection of cyber anomalies used machine learning methods for this study, such as Support Vector Machines (SVM), K-Nearest Neighbors (K-NN), and Neural Networks (NN) [6], using Random Forest as a viable method of classifying malware. In terms of monitored learning and performance, several studies have classified Gradient Boosted Trees, Random Forests, Neural Networks, and Support Vector Machines as highly predictive precision [7] [8]. While Gradient Boosted Trees had the highest precision, Random Forest achieved almost the same performance with minimal parameter setting [7]. In this study, we used Random Forest implementation on R with the RandomForest and Caret Library.
